chapter.title: Individuals with LD show intra-individual differences
chapter.content:
Individuals with LD show intra-individual differences

We will now move on to the third consensus statement. “Individuals with LD show intra-individual differences in skills and abilities.”

Intra-individual differences are differences in ability within an individual. For example, Mary may be good at public speaking, but becomes easily frustrated when trying to read, or a person may be great conversationalist, but have difficulty writing.

chapter.title: Intra-individual differences show a pattern of strengths and weaknesses
chapter.content:
Intra-individual differences show a pattern of strengths and weaknesses

For adults, these differences can affect a range of cognitive processes evident in academic achievement, employment and daily living activities. These differences show a pattern of strengths and weaknesses.

For example, an individual may be a slow and labored reader, but do well with math calculation or measurement.

chapter.title: Marked performance differences in specific areas of functioning are a sign of LD
chapter.content:
Marked performance differences in specific areas of functioning are a sign of LD

As another example, an individual may be able to read well at the word level, but have great difficulty comprehending what he or she has read. Just being able to read individual words is not enough to comprehend text. Individuals must be able to think about what they read by engaging in thinking skills such as making inferences, visualizing a person or scene, or making connections between what they are reading and their own experiences.

Each of these individuals exhibit profiles that may indicate learning disabilities because of marked performance difference in specific areas of functioning. Let’s look more deeply into what these ‘differences within the individual’ can mean. We will start out with characteristics identified by special education legislation.

chapter.title: Intra-individual differences identified by special education regulations
chapter.content:
Intra-individual differences identified by special education regulations

Specific intra-individual differences indicating learning disabilities are identified by special education regulations of the U.S. Department of Education. These areas focus on academic skills.

  • Oral expression
  • Listening comprehension
  • Mathematics calculation
  • Mathematics problem solving
  • Basic reading skills
  • Reading fluency skills
  • Reading comprehension
  • Written expression

For example, an individual could be very orally expressive and tell you the details of the latest story in the news. Or he could listen to a story and tell you every detail but not be able to write a sentence.

chapter.title: Intra-individual differences include learning strengths and weaknesses
chapter.content:
Intra-individual differences include learning strengths and weaknesses

Some individuals have limited ability to read words in isolation – like on a prescription label, but they are able to slowly make their way through reading passages and tell you what the main point of the passage is with great insight.

The individual variability is great. The key is that there are learning strengths combined with areas of distinct weaknesses.

chapter.title: Additional resources on special education regulations
chapter.content:
Additional resources on special education regulations

For more information on the relevant special education regulations, visit the U.S. Department of Education, Office of Special Education Programs’ Individuals with Disabilities Act (IDEA) website. Also, be sure to explore the additional resources provided at the end of this module.

chapter.title: Intra-individual differences identified by Rehabilitation Services Administration
chapter.content:
Intra-individual differences identified by Rehabilitation Services Administration

If we look to the field of vocational rehabilitation, which is an adult service, we see additional areas identified as intra-individual differences. Areas where strengths and weaknesses may vary include the following:

• Attention • Writing
• Reasoning • Spelling
• Processing • Calculation
• Memory • Physical coordination
• Communication • Social competence
• Reading • Emotional maturity

chapter.title: Broader set of intra-individual differences describe general areas of importance
chapter.content:
Broader set of intra-individual differences describe general areas of importance

As compared to special education regulations of the U.S. Department of Education, the Rehabilitation Services Administration has developed a broader set of intra-individual differences that can be attributed to LD. These are more general areas important to adult life that can contribute to poor adult functioning. This broad list is less accepted by the field.

This broader set of intra-individual differences could describe the brilliant businessperson who cannot remember to keep track of appointments, the skilled craftsman who cannot take or follow directions from others, and the poised and polished office worker who is afraid to send e-mails owing to his or her poor spelling and grammar.

chapter.title: Activity: Reflect on your experiences with adults with intra-individual differences
chapter.content:
Activity: Reflect on your experiences with adults with intra-individual differences

Take a moment to think about the adults you have known who demonstrated significant intra-individual differences. Consider your answers to the following questions:

  1. What kinds of significant intra-individual differences have you observed in the adults you’ve known?
  2. Do you think that any of these adults had a diagnosed LD?

Please share your reflections and read other teachers’ responses in the LINCS Disabilities in Adult Education Group before moving on.

When you have finished posting your reflections, continue to Consensus Statement #4.
